message: Thank you.   Yesterday, I was honored to be sworn in for the 115th Congress with my wife Brooke and two daughters, Caroline and Eloise (and their blankies). I'm humbled that you have continued to place your faith and trust in me to represent the Third District of Kansas.

Tonight, I was proud to join my colleagues from both sides of the aisle in sending a strong bipartisan message to rebuke the United Nations' misguided, anti-Israel resolution so we can get back on a path to a peaceful solution to conflict in the Middle East.

Congratulations to Donald J. Trump and Mike Pence on their official certification as the next President and Vice President of the United States. Today, I was able to participate in the peaceful transition of power in our nation, as the House and Senate officially certified the Electoral College results. As outgoing Vice-President Biden chaired today's session, it was a good reminder that while our nation faces many problems, the best way to tackle them is through ideas from both political parties that represent the views of all Americans. I look forward to working with President Trump, Vice President Pence, and Republicans and Democrats in Congress on a bold, bipartisan agenda in the coming months and years.
There‚Äôs been a lot of noise about repealing and replacing Obamacare lately. Let‚Äôs take a minute to remember some facts.
Blue lights in my office window tonight for #LawEnforcementAppreciationDay. One for each fallen KC officer in 2016.

I‚Äôm humbled and honored that my colleagues have placed their trust in me to serve as Chairman of the Legislative Branch Subcommittee on Appropriations. One of my top priorities since coming to Congress has been to rein in out-of-control federal spending and increase transparency with regard to how we spend taxpayers‚Äô hard-earned money. I‚Äôve always said that Congress must lead by example when it comes to fiscal responsibility, and chairing this subcommittee gives me the opportunity to follow through with that commitment. I look forward to providing Kansans and the American people with a more streamlined, efficient, and effective legislative branch in this new role.

On Monday, we observed Law Enforcement Appreciation Day in honor of the contributions that countless men and women in uniform have made to keep our communities safe and secure. Let us never forget the service and sacrifice of our law enforcement officers and let us continue to honor them with the gratitude and respect they deserve.

Today, I voted for the budget resolution that begins the process of replacing Obamacare. Our blueprint for a Better Way to fix America‚Äôs health care system will not involve a comprehensive, overly complex, and confusing 3,000-page bill in the mold of Nancy Pelosi‚Äôs infamous ‚Äúwe have to pass the bill so that you can find out what is in it.‚Äù  Instead, it will involve a step-by-step approach that may take time, but will be done correctly to achieve our goals of empowering patients and doctors ‚Äì not federal bureaucrats. It will protect those with pre-existing conditions and ensure the most vulnerable among us will have financial assistance in purchasing coverage of their choice without eliminating inexpensive coverage for everyone else. It will actually lower costs by increasing choice and competition, without imposing heavy-handed government mandates. It will provide what Kansans need ‚Äì accessibility, affordability, and quality ‚Äì all of which have failed under Obamacare.

"We must learn to live together as brothers or perish together as fools."  The only way to make true progress is to work together and overcome our differences. Thank you for your example, Dr. King.

It was an honor to join many community leaders at the 13th Annual Martin Luther King Jr. Legacy and Scholarship Awards Dinner in Overland Park tonight to celebrate the life and legacy of Dr. King. We‚Äôve come a long way since Dr. King and others crossed the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma and were beaten simply for demanding equality. But that journey is never-ending and our work is never done.   We cannot forget what our nation has been through or we run the risk of repeating history's mistakes. So we come together, like we did tonight, to honor our civil rights leaders. We tell our children and share with them their legacy so that the next generation can carry the torch of tolerance and justice. Thank you to Henry Lyons for organizing this annual event and bringing us together as a community.

Today, the President commuted the sentence of someone who leaked classified information that ended up in the hands of Osama bin Laden. Someone who exposed information that we know ended up directly aiding al Qaeda. To say that every American should be deeply disappointed is a grave understatement.

Check out my weekly newsletter below, where I talk about the 58th Presidential Inauguration, the House beginning the process of replacing Obamacare, and much more. If you want to subscribe to these weekly emails, visit www.yoder.house.gov.

It was great to welcome so many Kansans into my Washington, DC office to celebrate the peaceful transfer of power. Some constituents drove over sixteen hours through the middle of the night in order to get here. I was inspired to see the enthusiasm and patriotism of so many Americans who came from all over our country to celebrate our democracy together.

It was an honor to sit on the platform to witness the peaceful transfer of power as Donald J. Trump and Michael R. Pence were sworn in as the 45th President and 48th Vice President of the United States. I look forward to working with the new Administration in the coming months and years.   Thank you to President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle for the last 8 years serving our great nation. Brooke and I wish you both the best.

With all the Presidential Inaugural events, last week was historic and exciting. But now it's time to get to work. There are complex challenges we are facing as a nation like a staggering national debt and a federal government in desperate need of reforms. With a unified government, we will be able to work toward bipartisan solutions to improve the economy and make sure we get our country back on the right path.

Check out my weekly newsletter where I discuss how after the peaceful transfer of power, work begins for the new President and Congress, and much more. If you want to subscribe to these weekly emails, visit www.yoder.house.gov.

Earlier today, President Trump signed an executive order to approve the Keystone XL and Dakota Access Pipelines. These projects will be a long awaited shot in the arm after eight years of burdensome red tape that has hampered America‚Äôs energy economy.   My colleagues and I have worked for many years to break through the administrative blockade that has prevented these job producing projects from becoming a reality. Building the pipelines will increase economic growth, tap into America's vast energy supply, and will cut energy costs for hardworking Americans all across the country.   I am happy that the President has reinvigorated these projects which will continue to ensure that we are maximizing our nation‚Äôs natural resources as we move towards energy independence and less reliance on foreign powers that become seemingly more hostile every day.

Everyone should have the opportunity to pursue the American dream - and it starts with quality early education. It was great to welcome so many early childhood education advocates here to our nation‚Äôs capital this morning at the Congressional Head Start Breakfast. I was happy to see such a large turnout and I am honored to have been able to speak at this inspiring event. Since I came to Congress, advocating for Head Start has been a top priority of mine.  Also today, I met with a handful of National Head Start Association advocates from Kansas, including Kim Sill from Olathe Head Start, to discuss my continued support for this program, which serves many Kansas families and children to be prepared for modern education. I will continue to advocate for early education.

Advocates of National Head Start Association came to Capitol Hill yesterday to make sure that Kansas families and children have access to quality early education. Many families in the 3rd District depend on the Head Start program, and without Head Start, these children are at risk of falling behind in school.  In a time of deep division in our country, we can all unite in support of early childhood education. Thank you to the Kansas Head Start Association for coming to DC this week.

If you ever wonder if real people are heard in the halls of Congress, today was a great example. A young woman named Rachel Mast from Olathe walked into my office in DC years ago to advocate for the Achieving a Better Life Experience (ABLE) Act and she wasn‚Äôt going to leave without my support. The bill, now federal law, helps individuals with disabilities and their families better prepare for a financially secure and independent future through tax-free savings accounts. I was proud to co-sponsor the ABLE Act which passed with overwhelming bipartisan support 404-17. After almost a decade of work in DC, and then passing the law in KS, today Rachel was able to open her ABLE Savings plan account in Olathe.   Congratulations to all who tirelessly advocated for this bill, especially Rachel‚Äôs amazing parents, Jawanda and Jonathan. Special thanks to Kansas State Treasurer's Office and Treasurer Ron Estes, Kansas State Rep. Erin Davis, National Down Syndrome Society President Sara Weir, City of Olathe, KS Government Mayor Michael Copeland, and Inclusion Connections in Olathe. I couldn‚Äôt let this moment pass without congratulating everyone who worked so hard to make this day a reality. Thanks for letting me play a little part in this great success.

Thank you British Prime Minister Theresa May for making the trip to speak at the Congressional Republican retreat today. It was great to discuss strengthening ties between the United States and the United Kingdom, and I look forward to continuing our partnership.

We must be both a compassionate nation and a nation that keeps its citizens safe and we must find common ground to achieve both missions. Reforming and strengthening our vetting system is necessary and important step to continuing the long legacy of refugees coming to America. The Obama Administration rightly did this in 2011 when it paused refugee resettlement from Iraq for six months to prevent terrorist infiltration and again last year when it worked with Congress to sign our bill into law reforming the visa waiver program, which laid the groundwork for this executive order. Likewise, President Trump should have our nation's support to carry out his mission to protect our nation's borders, but he must do so without unnecessarily burdening lawful entrants into the United States or discriminating against specific religions  It's clear right now the order is being interpreted too broadly to block valid visas and green card holders. While a temporary pause in new admissions is appropriate - the President should work with Congress to come up with clear procedures to ensure that our refugee program can continue in the safest manner possible.

Since 1990, the OK Program has helped bridge the gap between law enforcement and the African-American community. This program has helped thousands of men including Brian Miller, who I met with in my DC office today where he shared his story with me. Brian Miller, who is now the National Executive Director of this program, was also joined by Executive Director Darron Story, and Founder Donald Northcross to discuss the importance of OK Program in Kansas City. The safety of our citizens here on American soil is our top priority. Our borders must be secure against anyone who would enter our country illegally, especially those who wish to exploit our nation‚Äôs generosity and compassion. However, compassion and security are not conflicting ideals. We must find common ground and achieve both missions for the good of our country.  I look forward to working with my colleagues in Congress to come up with clear procedures to ensure that our refugee program can continue in the safest manner possible.  I offer my office as a resource to any families in my district who may be negatively impacted by the recent Executive Order blocking travel to the United States and urge them to reach out via yoder.house.gov if they need assistance.

We discussed the importance of special education funding and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), the school lunch program, and making sure that we maintain our great public school system through local control. I have advocated for power to return to parents, teachers, and the local school boards, and I will continue to push for this.   Thank you to this group of Kansas School Board members for coming to DC, including Shawnee Mission Board Member Brad Stratton, Kansas City, Kansas Board Member Evelyn Hill, Olathe School Board Member Amy Martin and Board President Rick Schier, and Rob Gilligan from the Kansas Association of School Boards. And most importantly, thank you for your service to our communities.

Helping our nation‚Äôs veterans who have sacrificed so much to keep our nation safe remains one of my top priorities in Congress. Yesterday, with my support the House passed three important bills to streamline access to care for veterans, as well as provide new and better opportunities for veteran-owned businesses and veterans seeking employment.   The WINGMAN Act ‚Äì HR 512 ‚Äì will give congressional staff better access to information as they work to secure the proper benefits and treatment for veterans having problems at the VA. If you are a veteran struggling with federal bureaucracy and in need of assistance, please contact my District Office at 913-621-0832 and we will do everything we can to help you, and this bill will give us better tools to do it.   Additionally, the BRAVE Act ‚Äì HR 974 ‚Äì and the HIRE Vets Act ‚Äì HR 244 ‚Äì are two important bills that will allow the VA to prioritize awarding contracts to businesses based on the number of veterans employed at that business and establish a federal program recognizing private businesses that employ veterans and engage in community service to help our vets. If you want more information about these bills, or any bills under consideration in Congress, visit www.congress.gov and utilize the search tool at the top of the page.

Every Kansan deserves the opportunity to chase their dreams and build a better future for themselves and their family. The best way to equip them with the tools to do that is making sure they have the ability to seek higher education and prepare themselves for their careers. Today, I met with Johnson County Community College to talk about the best ways to meet these goals and how Congress can help. We talked about higher education funding and student financial aid programs like Pell Grants, which I utilized to put myself through college at the University of Kansas. Wishing a Happy Valentine's Day to Brooke and my two little valentines!

That is 211,000 too many, and why one of the bills we passed this week establishes a federal program recognizing private businesses that employ veterans and engage in community service to help our vets.

I call upon my colleagues to share in that goal. It is a moral, fiscal, and national security imperative.

I enjoyed meeting with constituents this morning who shared their personal stories about how the Affordable Care Act has affected them and their families. It‚Äôs important as we have this debate that we listen to differing viewpoints to find out what has and what hasn't worked so we can repair our broken health care system by replacing the ACA with solutions that work for everyone.   Perhaps the biggest takeaway from this morning‚Äôs meeting is the concern that those who weren‚Äôt able to obtain affordable health insurance because of pre-existing conditions prior to the ACA will be left out in the cold as we replace it. We must ensure that does not happen as we replace the ACA. But at the same time, we must ensure that costs don‚Äôt skyrocket for everyone else as a result, as we saw under Obamacare. We‚Äôll do it by building a smarter, patient-centered system with more choices and competition for coverage at a lower cost. And it‚Äôs my hope that we‚Äôll do it with bipartisan support.   Thank you to those who have taken the time to share your experiences with me. I value your input and will keep it in mind as we move forward. If you‚Äôd like to share your story on how the law has affected you ‚Äì positively or negatively ‚Äì you can send me a note by visiting www.yoder.house.gov and clicking ‚ÄúEmail Me‚Äù under the ‚ÄúContact‚Äù tab.

Cutting VAWA grants would mean we are failing to protect some of the most vulnerable women, children, and families in our country. We feel strongly that Congress and the Trump Administration must ensure the policies and procedures in place at the federal level must remain intact so we can meet their needs.

It was great to join my friend Rep. Lynn Jenkins to co-emcee the Kansas Chamber of Commerce‚Äôs Annual Dinner in Topeka last night. Hearing directly from veterans in the Third District is a top priority as we fulfill our commitment to those who have served this country. I had the opportunity to sit down and visit with my Veterans' Advisory Committee this morning to discuss issues that are currently affecting veterans and active duty military. We covered recent and pending legislation related to veterans and U.S. servicemembers, the Veterans' Choice Act, and other efforts to improve patient care at VA facilities. Additionally, we discussed the VA Claims process and suggested remedies to alleviate the back log.  It's crucial to hear firsthand from veterans of multiple eras and branches of service which provides a unique perspective. Special thanks to VFW Veterans of Foreign Wars of Lenexa, KS #7397 Commander "Big Mike" Petersen for hosting our meeting today.

Each and every day, thousands of women take refuge in domestic abuse shelters and countless lives are saved thanks to the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA). One of the shelters directly impacted federal VAWA funding in the Third District is SAFEHOME, which I visited this morning to meet with staff about the important life-saving work they‚Äôre doing. I‚Äôm committed to supporting the essential federal grant funding that VAWA provides through the Department of Justice, which is working to protect our nation‚Äôs domestic violence victims and families. Yesterday, I wrote a letter to President Trump asking that the Administration prioritize these grants and do not place them on the chopping block for cuts as we work to balance our budget and get our fiscal house in order.    Thank you to Janee‚Äô Hanzlick, President and CEO of SAFEHOME and Dr. Jay Lehnertz, SAFEHOME Board Chair, for taking time to update me on the critical services SAFEHOME provides in our community and having me back for another visit.

What happened at Austin's Bar & Grill last night in Olathe was a senseless tragedy. Each year I have the privilege of nominating students from across our community to a United States Service Academy. Last night, I hosted a reception for this year's nominees and their families to present them a certificate of nomination. These students are the future leaders of our country, whose patriotism, desire for service above self, and academic accomplishment is astounding. Thank you to the Olathe School District for allowing me to hold our reception in the Olathe East High School Library, to the American Legion Post 153, Olathe, Kansas for the presentation of colors and to retired Col. Tony Hofmann, Public Works Director for the City of Overland Park and USMA class of 1990, who shared his experience while at West Point and gave a leadership challenge from American History. I am so proud of the strong Indian community we have in the Third District. Tonight, at the Let us Stand Together Prayer Vigil, thousands of concerned citizens came together to support one another and the Indian community in this time of great tragedy. I was able to visit with and encourage Alok Madasani, who survived the shooting last week. Among other things, we discussed his hope to get back to his favorite sports soon - including cricket.  We also remembered the life of Srinivas Kuchibhotla, who sadly passed last week,  and the heroism of Ian Grillot, who is still in the hospital. Great to visit with my friends from ProstateNetwork at the airport heading to DC to discuss medical research for prostate cancer.

Providing research funding for cures to rare diseases is one of my top priorities in Congress, and I‚Äôve been meeting with advocates all week for Rare Disease Week on Capitol Hill to hear their stories. Today, I met with Marti and Roger Dart from Leawood, as well as Karey Padding from Andover, of the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation to talk about how their lives have been personally affected by cystic fibrosis. The disease affects more than 30,000 people in the United States, with approximately 1,000 new cases diagnosed each year. During our discussion, we talked about the needs of the cystic fibrosis community as we continue the process of repairing our broken health care system, as well as the importance of funding for the National Institutes of Health (NIH) for research and removing red tape at the Food and Drug Administration to facilitate cystic fibrosis drug discovery and development. As a strong advocate for increased funding to finding cures and treatments for rare diseases like cystic fibrosis, I will continue to do my part so that we can advance understanding of this little-known disease and to create new treatments and eventually find a cure.

Third grade students at Rosehill Elementary School in Lenexa in the Shawnee Mission School District opened a lemonade stand. In their classes they‚Äôve been studying economics and are using their knowledge to raise funds for the Alex's Lemonade Stand Foundation, which works to defeat childhood cancer. I had to stop by and support their hard work. They were so excited to tell me about this project and combating childhood cancer. And, I might add their lemonade was good. Thank you to Rosehill Principal Cory Strathman for your leadership and to third grade teachers Amanda DeWeerd, Lauren Langhofer, and Meghan Minardi for challenging these students.

It was an honor to visit with my friends at the Rare Disease Expo in Topeka this morning and call attention to the millions of people around the world whose daily lives are impacted by a rare disease. There are around 7,000 identified rare diseases in the world ‚Äì affecting more than 30 million Americans, half of whom are children. Because of how rare these diseases are, most of them lack the awareness, funding, and research to find cures. Stunningly ‚Äì 95% of rare diseases do not have a single FDA approved drug treatment. That‚Äôs why federal funding for research at the National Institutes of Health is so important. The private sector simply doesn‚Äôt have the resources to invest in research for every disease. I will continue to fight for NIH funding at the federal level and work to bring these dollars to Kansas institutions that play such an important role in fighting rare disease, like the University of Kansas Medical Center and Children's Mercy Hospital.  Thank you to Eden Lord and her daughter Cambria of Overland Park for inviting me to attend. It was also great to see Kelly Ranallo, a rare patient advocate for Rare KC. I look forward to working together to bring awareness to rare diseases and find treatments and cures for the patients and families who fight these diseases every day.

Last week, I joined my family in Yoder, Kansas to celebrate the life of my Grandma Edna, who passed recently at the age of 105.   I was very close to my Grandma as many of us are to our grandparents. She was a sweet and kind woman who could tell a good story, never met a stranger, and had an infectious laugh. I spent much of my childhood listening to her hum church hymns while cooking a country meal or quilting another masterpiece.   One of 14 children, she grew up in another era, a time without a cell phones or television, or even electricity and the other modern conveniences we take for granted today. Yet she somehow survived and had a remarkable life. She saw hard times, from the dust bowl, to the great depression, to countless world events over the past century.   She also saw great times. She lived her entire life near Yoder where she raised her children on the same farm that I grew up on. She was a living embodiment of the values that helped make America the greatest country in the world. She was guided every day by her faith in God, her love of her family, and her belief in hard work and self-determination.   In her later years, she passed the time reading her Bible and of course quilting and playing lots of games. The last time I was with her recently, we played Bingo together and wiped out the competition at her retirement home one last time. She was sharp until her final hours.   Grandma, we were so blessed to have so many wonderful years with you. Thank you for being the best Grandma anyone could ever have. As you pass on to eternal life, please know that you are an inspiration to all of us every day. May you rest in peace.

Today, I cast a vote in favor of fixing our broken health care system, to choose markets over mandates, innovation over regulation, and patients over bureaucrats. There are two questions I answer with respect to every vote on the House floor: is this the right bill for my district and will it make the future of America stronger. The American Health Care Act succeeds on both.  Obamacare‚Äôs big government mandates, taxes, and spending are destroying our health care system today. The last insurance providers are pulling out of Iowa and dozens of counties across Tennessee and Virginia ‚Äì leaving millions on the individual market with no options for care ‚Äì and Kansas could be next. The American Health Care Act makes necessary and immediate repairs to the devastated system left in Obamacare‚Äôs wake, and will provide more choice, more competition, lower premiums, and greater access to care in the future. It reduces taxes and spending, and lowers federal deficits.   Let me be clear ‚Äì no one with preexisting conditions can or will be denied affordable coverage under the AHCA now or ever. In reality, our bill frees states to develop innovative ways to provide them with better coverage than they receive now and invests nearly $140 billion to help them succeed in doing it.  We are seeing the dangerous collapse of Obamacare play out across the country. Rather than forcing Americans to buy plans they don‚Äôt want or can‚Äôt afford, regulating insurance providers out of the market altogether, or leaving people with no options to choose from, the AHCA makes the necessary changes to repair our health care system that‚Äôs collapsing before our eyes. For these reasons, today I voted yes.

Despite misinformation being spread, no one with preexisting conditions can be denied access to coverage under the American Health Care Act. We specifically prohibit it. Here‚Äôs the bill text from Section 136:
Great read from my friend Cathy McMorris Rodgers on what our bill does for people with preexisting conditions.

MYTH: The American Health Care Act will price those with preexisting conditions out of the market, making health care unaffordable for them.  FACT: Under the AHCA, rules that prevent insurance providers from denying coverage or charging more expensive rates based on health status remain the law of the land.   If states can show they have new innovative solutions to protect individuals with preexisting conditions in a better way, they can waive out of this regulatory framework ONLY for individuals who have gone more than two months without purchasing insurance.  As long as you have continuous coverage, you CANNOT be charged more based on health status in ANY state.  Even if you have a gap in coverage, insurers can only charge you a higher premium for 12 months, then you are returned to paying the same premiums as everyone else.  On top of the $130 billion investment in risk mitigation programs in the bill, the AHCA devotes $8 billion over five years to further stabilize the premiums of the small subset of people who would be affected.  ***Click below for links to the bill text supporting these facts.

Congress owes it to the American people to be good stewards of taxpayer dollars and ensure that we are getting the resources to help purchase health insurance to those who really need it.   In a study, the Senate Homeland Security Committee has found the Obama Administration awarded Affordable Care Act subsidies to more than 500,000 individuals who were not eligible to receive them. Under federal law, illegal immigrants and other foreign nationals who are not lawfully present in the US are not allowed to receive taxpayer subsidies to purchase health insurance ‚Äì something we can all agree on. However, the ACA was structured to presume eligibility of an applicant from the onset, allowing the Administration to disperse subsidies while attempting to verify eligibility and resulting in the unlawful disbursements to those 500,000 individuals.   Today, we passed the Verify First Act, which makes simple but important structural changes to the law to prevent taxpayer subsidies under the ACA or premium tax credits under the American Health Care Act (AHCA) from being dispersed until we can determine the legal status of the recipient. It‚Äôs an example of Congress working in a bipartisan manner to save taxpayer dollars and get health care resources to the people need it, not people here in our country illegally.

Diversity and inclusion are things that make our American culture, democracy, and economy better and stronger. Immigrants who come to our country legally, respect our laws, and work hard to contribute to our economy deserve every opportunity to achieve the American Dream. That's why I'm working to reform our legal immigration system to help these people, many of whom are stuck in massive green card backlogs due to our current laws. I'm pushing for my bill, the Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act, that would remove the per-nation caps on employment-based green cards that are forcing immigrants from larger nations like India or China to wait decades for permanent residence while others from smaller nations only have to wait one or two years. Childcare and early childhood education is an issue that affects every single family in our community and around the country. That‚Äôs why it's important that we stand together ‚Äì Republicans and Democrats ‚Äì to help working families deal with the exploding costs of childcare, which have increased by 168% over the last 25 years. On Wednesday, I hosted a roundtable discussion on this issue at the Mastin Street KinderCare location in Overland Park to talk with KinderCare Education officials, childcare experts, parents, and advocates about my bipartisan bill, the Promoting Affordable Childcare for Everyone (PACE) Act.   The PACE Act makes important updates and reforms to our childcare tax credits and flex spending accounts to help middle class and low-income families pay for care for their children. It raises the value of the childcare tax credit by 15% for all families, indexes the credit to inflation to help keep up the pace with rising costs, and makes the credit refundable so families who are at or near the poverty line will have access to it. We also enhance the childcare flex spending accounts by increasing the amount of pre-tax dollars families can put into FSAs by 50% and index the new cap to inflation.   This is not a partisan issue. Every American family, across both political parties, in all regions of the country, wants to be able to afford quality early-childhood education to prepare their children for the future. I want to thank Mastin Street KinderCare and Center Director Rachel Dorman for hosting this discussion, Kim Engelman and other advocates from Child Care Aware who have been strong proponents of our bill, and to all the parents who made time in their busy schedules to be there this week. I opposed President Obama's ‚Äòtemporary stopgap measure‚Äô as he called it five years ago - in which he said ‚Äòthis is not amnesty, this is not immunity, this is not a path to citizenship‚Äô - because it would leave many undocumented immigrants in limbo, with no real status. While the program may have been conceived with good intentions, it has served as a magnet, bringing tens of thousands of new immigrants, exacerbating our illegal immigration challenges, and creating a humanitarian crisis at the border. America is a nation of immigrants, a nation of laws, and one that fundamentally believes in the principle of fairness. We have millions of high-skilled immigrants in America who have come here legally, who follow our laws, pay our taxes, and contribute billions of dollars to our economy. These are individuals from nations like India and China who work hard, many of whom who want to start their own small businesses to create more American jobs, but cannot because of backlogs created by arbitrary and unnecessary roadblocks in our employment-based green card laws. Many immigrants from those nations will go their entire life waiting for permanent residence, while others from small countries cut them in line and receive green cards after two or three years. We can all agree that is a grave injustice.   Yesterday, I met with Prakash Wadhwa from Overland Park while he was in DC with an advocacy organization called Skilled Immigrants In America and talked about my bill, the Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act to help these people. My bill would make the system a first-come, first-serve system based on merit ‚Äì because what you can contribute to the economy should matter more than the nation listed on your birth certificate. Importantly, it fixes an existing issue in the proper legal immigration channels, which are all too often forgotten or ignored in our debates over what to do about those who have crossed our borders illegally. The bill has bipartisan support from 284 Members of Congress ‚Äì nearly a veto-proof majority ‚Äì and we are continuing the push with help from groups like Skilled Immigrants in America. Thank you to Prakash and the rest of the group for meeting with me.
